Headline: Certified Agile Coach || Strategic Scrum¬†Master ||

Instead of running in a race where you don't know the end goal, it's great to take a pause, reflect on what you really want to do and then resume. An arrow can be shot only by pulling it backward and 'holding' it for a moment.

Headline: Product Marketing @ Uberall
Comment:
One of the core reasons is reinventing oneself.

With AI and emerging tech (and supersmart young minds), merely upskilling is not enough. You must reinvent yourself periodically and it happens by taking a step back and asking really basic (read dumb) questions about why you do what you do and why you're the right person to do it. And, sabbaticals help a lot here I guess. 

Let me come back and comment if it really helped. Because I heard someone saying ‚Äì there is a fine line between bravery and stupidity (and can only be realized by looking at the outcome üòÄ)

Headline: Helping Enterprises Modernize with High-Performance Teams | AI in Software development | Extreme Programming | DevOps | Agile
Comment:
Earlier people with single income household were not able to do, given the family responsibilities. But that is now changing with double income households and also with more awareness on personal financial planning. 

And these planned breaks are helping to analyze own core values and purpose. And also helping to understand our priorities. 

Stepping back and looking on what progress we have made till date and which direction we want to go further is a good way to live life aligned to our true self.

Headline: Founder at Ai Health Highway üåçüåéüåè #hiring
Comment:
Easier said than done - but trying to answer one question genuinely, honestly as early as possible "What is the purpose of my life" may help. Finding the right balance between Ikigai - what you love > what the world needs > what you be paid for > what you are good at... finding the right balance between these four aspects is challenging
The world order is changing, earlier it was like you studied for 10+2+3/4/5 years and chose your career where you worked for 10/20/30 years. The technology shift is so fast now that what you learnt in the past 4-5 years is no longer relevant when you enter the job market...learn > unlearn > relearn needs to happen fast.

Headline: Professor of Practice | Deep-Tech, Incubation, Technology Commercialization

Headline: New Business Development & Ops |
Comment:
I think this will start changing slowly. The last few decades have been people working tirelessly and only taking a break when mentally and physically exhausted and feeling purposeless - hence ‚Äúcareer breaks‚Äù.

People have now started realising the importance of health and therefore managing it better WHILE working hard! So this trend of career breaks might actually be going down in years to come - though not completely eliminated, which is how it should be!

Headline: Consulting and Product Leader | 15+ years of leading Digital Transformation across Retail, B2C Marketplaces, Supply Chain
Comment:
The stats reveals our modern work culture
First came the hustle culture; work for 80 -90 hrs/week and then people are taking sabbaticals and career breaks to catch up on health and fitness..I am being reminded of the Hare and Tortoise story much too often..The Hare sprints and then takes rest to catch its breath while the tortoise cruises along slowly and steadily.. Seems like the modern world fantasizes the hare a lot more than the tortoise.. Age old wisdom have turned upside down!¬†

Headline: Startups, Growth and Investments | Partner, Favcy Venture Builders | Equity and Debt
